metadata.title: Bimetallic sites supported on N-doped graphene ((Fe,Co)/N-GN) as a new catalyst for NO oxidation: A theoretical investigation

Table 3 Paths Ea (eV) A (s−1) E-R(path1/2) 2.6 1.34 × 1022 E-R(path3/4) 2.8 1.34 × 1022 L-H(path5) 1.5 2.36 × 1020 Bimetallic sites supported on N-doped graphene ((Fe,Co)/N-GN) as a new catalyst for NO oxidation: A theoretical investigation Zhengyang Gao a ⁎ Xiaoshuo Liu a ⁎ Ang Li a Xiang Li a Xunlei Ding b Weijie Yang a a School of Energy and Power Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Baoding 071003, China School of Energy and Power Engineering North China Electric Power University Baoding 071003 China b School of Mathematics and Physics, North China Electric Power University, Beijing 102206, China School of Mathematics and Physics North China Electric Power University Beijing 102206 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Nitric oxide (NO) releasing from power plants has caused global concerns. Converting NO to NO2 by catalytic oxidation technology is a promising method for NO elimination. Adsorption characteristics of corresponding gases and mechanism of NO oxidation on the surface of (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst were systematically investigated via density functional theory calculation. The detailed reaction paths in mechanism of Eley-Rideal and Langmuir-Hinshelwood were studied respectively and the thermodynamic and kinetic analysis of each path were performed to further understand the impact of temperature on the chemical equilibrium constant and reaction rate constant. It was observed that NO can be easily oxidized to NO2 on the surface of (Fe,Co)/N-GN with the smallest energy barriers about 0.17 eV in E–R mechanism, but the oxidation of NO in boiler is more likely to take place in L-H mechanism due to lower desorption barrier of generated NO2. Besides, we found CO played a promoting role in removal of residual oxygen atom, and H2O and SO2 had little impact on reaction under 800 K. We hope this work can not only lay a foundation for theoretical study of NO oxidation, but also provide a guideline for NO elimination in the coal-fired power plants. Keywords Metal-doped graphene NO catalytic oxidation Density functional theory Thermodynamic and kinetic analysis 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) emission, containing Nitric oxide (NO), Nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and Nitric oxides (N2O), has been recognized as a main source of air pollution across the world. As a kind of hazardous gas, NOx could lead to greenhouse effect, formation of acid rain, occurrence of photochemical smog, damage of ozone, and hurt of human nervous system [1–3], and therefore the elimination of NOx has drawn global concern. Currently, NOx coming from coal-fired power stationary has become the principal source of its anthropogenic pollution, and the amount of NO takes up the largest proportion of NOx in flue gas [4], demonstrating the abatement of NO from power plants would be more than important. Various methods have been proposed to decline the emission of NO, among which selective catalytic reduction with ammonia (SCR-NH3) is recognized as one of the most efficient methods, and it has been widely employed in power plants currently [5,6]. However, SCR-NH3 still suffers some ineligible shortcomings in actual operation, such as catalyst poisoning [7], poor efficiency at low temperatures [8], catalyst abrasion at high temperatures [9], and ammonia slipping [10]. In particular, ammonia leakage can result in critical consequences because ammonia is a kind of toxic gas that threatens human's health by hurting eyes, skins and respiratory systems [11]. Moreover, injected ammonia can react with sulfur dioxide (SO2) in flue gas to generate ammonium sulfate ((NH4)2SO4) as well as ammonium bisulfate (NH4HSO4) in boilers, and the generated ammonium salts would condense at low temperature, making the heat exchangers blocked [12], which can lead to economic losses and even huge safety accidents. Therefore, it is very valuable to seek new technologies to replace SCR-NH3 method, in order to realize efficient de-nitrification as secure as possible. A novel idea to solve stationary source NO has been proposed by oxidizing NO to NO2 using catalysts [1,13], and it has shown great feasibility because after NO molecule is oxidized to NO2, NO2 can be well removed through the desulfurization slurry in wet flue gas desulfurization system (WFGD), utilizing good water solubility of NO2 [14]. However, it is very hard for NO to be converted to NO2 in flue gas [15], as manifested by NO still occupies main proportion of NOx in boilers, even though the existence of excess oxygen at high operation temperature. Therefore, developing well-performance catalysts to decrease the oxidation energy barrier is of great importance to achieve wide application of NO catalytic oxidation technology in the near future, which has become a hotspot in the fields of energy and catalytic science. Yang et al [4] carried out a theoretical research on NO catalytic oxidation by the surface of single atom iron doped graphene (Fe/GN), and they found Fe/GN can promote NO oxidation obviously with a small barrier of 0.04 eV, but the large desorption barrier of NO2 (2.07 eV) would hinder its catalytic performance seriously. Esrafili et al [16] performed a comprehensive work about NO catalytic oxidation on the surface of single atom silicon catalyst embedded on boron-nitride nanotubes, and though they found that this catalyst can facilitate NO oxidation in the view of energy barrier, the reaction was not favorable in thermodynamics at low temperature, making catalytic reaction unspontaneous and reversible. Precious metal particles such as Pt [17,18], Ru [19], Au [20,21] were thought as ideal choices for NO catalytic oxidation due to their great stability together with high catalytic activity, and corresponding researches have demonstrated that the conversion rate of NO by precious metal catalysts supported on TiO2 could up to 93% (Pt/TiO2), 94% (Ru/TiO2), and 85% (Au/TiO2) respectively on real operation conditions [15]. However, high cost of these precious metal catalysts becomes a huge obstacle restricting their wider application in commercial, and hence it is very urgent to find cheap alternatives to further promote NO catalytic oxidation technology. Non-precious metal catalysts doped in nitrogen modified carbonaceous materials (M/N-C) have been viewed as one of the most promising substitutions for noble metal catalysts [22], but traditional preparation method of M/N-C such as direct pyrolysis of metal organic framework (MOF) would cause serious catalyst agglomeration [23]. In order to get over the agglomeration of catalysts, some doped metal atoms into N-modified graphene or graphene-like Nano-sheet materials, and they found these materials could anchor scattered metal atoms very well [24,25]. Wang et al. [26]designed a stable N-modified graphene-based catalyst with double active sites in experiment, denoted as (Fe,Co)/N-GN, and they found that (Fe,Co)/N-GN showed wonderful performance on oxygen activation [27], which has been recognized as an essential step for a series of reaction processes [28], such as oxygen reduction reaction [29], NO oxidation [4], and CO oxidation [30–32]. In addition, plenty of works evidenced that dual metal active sites catalysts based on carbonaceous materials showed compelling performance on catalytic oxidation reactions [32,33]. Wang et al [32] investigated the CO oxidation on Fe-Pt co-doped graphene ((Fe,Pt)/GN), and they found the energy barrier of this reaction was relative low (1.15 eV). In addition, Tian et al [33] designed a compelling catalyst which was described as Fe-Fe dual sites catalyst based on carbon nitride (Fe2/C3N4), and they observed perfect catalytic performance using this catalyst on alkene oxidation in experiment. Considering works above, it is natural for us to assume that (Fe,Co)/N-GN would exhibit great catalytic activity in NO oxidation. Herein, a theoretical calculation via density functional theory (DFT) was performed to reveal the oxidation mechanism of NO by O2 on the surface of (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst. Firstly, all possible adsorption approaches of corresponding gases (O, O2, NO, NO2, and NO together with O2) on catalyst were considered to get valuable information such as initial optimized structures for reaction paths. Secondly, various reaction paths were acquired by searching transition states (TS) and related intermediates (IM). In this part, two kinds of reaction mechanisms of Eley-Rideal (E–R) and Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) were involved to guarantee the comprehensiveness of our work. Thirdly, energy profiles of NO catalytic oxidation in distinct reaction paths were plotted to obtain rate determining steps of each path, and the role of CO played in reaction would be talked about deeply. Fourthly, thermodynamic and kinetic analyses were performed to get temperature effect on reaction equilibrium constants (K) and reaction rate constants (KTST). Lastly, the effect of H2O and SO2 on reaction was researched in order to evaluating the anti-poisoning capacity of (Fe,Co)/N-GN. In this work, we can not only uncover the mechanism of NO catalytic oxidation by oxygen on the surface of (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst, but also evidence that (Fe,Co)/N-GN could be a great catalyst for NO oxidation in coal-fired power plants. 2 Computational details Method and basis set are critical factors for the accuracy of calculation results and time consumption. Herein, all structure optimizations as well as frequency calculations for reactants (R), adsorption initial structures (IS), intermediates states (IM), transition states (TS), adsorption final states (FS) and products (P) were carried out in the method of PBE, utilizing Stuttgart group basis set (SDD) for Fe as well as Co atoms, and def2-SVP Alhrichs basis set for other atoms [34]. The selection of PBE method was determined due to its wide application in works related to interactions of NOx with metal-doped graphene [35–39]. Besides, considering the relativistic effects of heavy atoms, SDD basis set was used for Fe and Co atoms in order to save computational cost [40]. In addition, D3 dispersion corrections for gradients and energies were carried out taking into account the influence of van der Waals dispersion [41,42], and vibration frequency analysis was made to check the number of imaginary frequency of TS, and obtain zero point energy correction. Furthermore, in order to guarantee the correct connection between TS and corresponding IM, intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) calculations were carried out. Notably, each structure of IS in this paper was computed under different spin multiplicities to acquire its ground state, and IM and TS followed in corresponding path would use the same spin multiplicities as IS, and therefore crossing of potential energy surfaces was not considered in our calculation. In this work, most quantum chemistry calculation were conducted at Gaussian09 software package [43]. Herein, binding energy (Eb1) of metal atom (M1) into substance, as well as adsorption energy (Eads) of gas molecules on (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst were calculated from equations below, respectively: E b1 = E F e , C o / N − G N − E s u b + M 2 − E M 1 E a d s = E F e , C o / N − G N + g a s − E F e , C o / N − G N − E g a s Where E(Fe,Co)/N-GN , Esub+M1 , EM2 , Egas , and E(Fe,Co)/N-GN+gas represent the Gibbs free energy of (Fe,Co)/N-GN, (Fe,Co)/N-GN with single metal atom (M2), the other single metal atom (M1), gas molecule, and whole system respectively. As defined here, more negative values of Eb/Eads means stronger binding/adsorption strength. The energy barrier (Ea ) and reaction heat (ΔE) have been obtained for each reaction step, which could be calculated through the following equations, respectively [4]. Obviously, smaller Ea means easier occurrence of reaction step, and higher negative value of ΔE corresponds to larger heat release. E a = E T S − E I S Δ E = E I M − E I S Where ETS, EIS, EIM represents the Gibbs free energy of transition state, initial state, and intermediate state, respectively. Thermodynamic analysis of each reaction was performed by exploring the equilibrium constant (K) [44] and it can be obtained through the equation below: Δ G = G F S − G I S = − R T L n k Where GIS is the Gibbs free energy of initial state and GFS is the Gibbs free energy of finial state, kJ·k−1. Kinetic characteristics for each reaction paths were acquired according to kinetic analysis by conventional transition state theory (TST) from 298.15 K to 1000 K, and the equation to calculate reaction rate constant (KTST ) [45,46] is listed as follows: K T S T = k B T h × exp ( − E a R T ) × Q T S Q A Q B Where Ea is the energy barrier of reaction step in Gibbs energy, eV；KB is the Boltzmann constant, 8.6173303 × 10−5 eV·k−1; T is the Kelvin temperature of each reaction, k; h is the Planck constant, 6.582119514 × 10−16 eV·s; QTS , QA and QB are partial function of transition state TS, reactant A and reactant B. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Catalyst model Rational research model is directly related to the substantially accurate result. According to our previous study [47] and some investigations of others [32,48], aromatic cluster model can not only simulate metal-doped graphene perfectly, but also is suitable for exploring mechanism of gas adsorption and heterogeneous catalytic reaction on the surface of graphene. Therefore, a finite carbonaceous cluster model containing 60 carbon atoms was used to simulate the graphene substance, with dangling bonding saturated by hydrogen atoms (GN: C60H20), and then (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst model was set up via replacing eight carbon atoms with six nitrogen atoms, one iron atom and one cobalt atom on graphene. ((Fe,Co)/N-GN: FeCoN6C52H20). In order to evidence the weak boundary effect of cluster model and guarantee the correct selection of method as well as basis sets in this research, the structure of (Fe,Co)/N-GN has been optimized by Gaussian09 and Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP 5.4.1) [49] respectively (see Fig.1 ), and corresponding parameters were summarized in Table 1 , noted that the work using VASP adopted the same calculation parameters as our previous investigations [50,51]. The comparison between cluster model and periodic model was carried out and the result indicated these models were very close in geometry, which suggested the construction of cluster model was rational and acceptable. Moreover, the binding energies of Fe, Co, and Fe together with Co on substance are -4.82 eV, -5.14 eV, and -12.28 eV respectively, and therefore it is pretty hard for metal atom catalyst to form clusters or nanoparticles in operation, which can ensure the normal work of this catalyst in actual operation. This conclusion is in great agreement with the high stability that (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst showed in experiment [27]. 3.2 Gas adsorption Adsorption is the initial step of chemical reaction. With the intention of acquiring the most stable configuration of different gas molecules adsorbed on the surface of catalyst, various possible initial structures have been considered and each structure owning the lowest energy was showed in Fig. 2 . Obviously, there was a manifest uplift of iron atom and cobalt atom in adsorption processes, and it is a common phenomenon in doped-graphene adsorption systems [47]. Besides geometric deformation, charge transfers (Δq) took place during gases adsorption, and the variation of mulliken charge as well as corresponding adsorption energy have been obtained in Table 2 . From Table 2, we can observe the graphene substance is always donating electrons to other atoms in adsorption system, suggesting the substance can not only play a role of support, but also take part in the reaction via exchanging electrons with metal atoms and gas molecules. Moreover, the adsorption investigation provides some important information for research of reaction mechanism. As for adsorption of oxygen molecule, the bond length of OO is enhanced to 1.43 Å from that of its gas phase (1.23 Å), and the adsorption energy of oxygen on (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst (-1.23 eV) is nearly same as that on Pt single atom catalyst doped on single vacancy defective graphene (Pt/SV) (-1.32 eV [52]), which further evidences there is a great activation of O2 during adsorption using (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst and it is reasonable for us to expect this compelling O2 activation capacity could lead to great catalytic effect on NO oxidation. Besides, the huge adsorption energy of NO2 molecule (-2.85 eV) and single O atom (-5.09 eV) suggest generated NO2 desorption may be relative hard for NO catalytic oxidation using (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst, and the escape of the second NO2 should be more than tougher than that of the first NO2. Furthermore, the adsorption order of reaction gases on catalyst is an important issue on reaction mechanism, and we must take into consideration of both adsorption energy and volume fraction of corresponding gases. Though adsorption energy of oxygen (-1.23 eV) is slightly lower than that of nitric oxide (-1.56 eV), considering the volume fraction of oxygen (4% [4]) in flue gas is far more than that of nitric oxide (200 ppm [4]), we still judged oxygen would be adsorbed on catalyst first in E–R reaction mechanism. Even if similar study predicted catalytic oxidation tended to take place through paths of E–R mechanism using graphene-based bimetallic atom catalyst [32], they couldn't give detailed reaction process to evidence higher energy barriers of paths in L-H mechanism, causing great puzzle to its correctness. In fact, the energy of co-adsorption of oxygen and nitric oxide on (Fe,Co)-N/GN catalyst via L-H mechanism is up to -2.26 eV, which is pretty higher than that of oxygen and nitric oxide individually. Therefore, when we explored the catalytic oxidation of NO, both E–R and L–H mechanisms were investigated, in order to guarantee comprehensive understanding of NO oxidation using (Fe,Co)-N/GN catalyst. It is worth noting that Mars–van Krevelen mechanism is also very important in heterogeneous catalysis, such as catalytic oxidation of CO [53,54], and cyclohexane [55] on metal oxides surface. However, (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst does not belong to metal oxides, suggesting no lattice oxygen involved in lattice of catalyst, and therefore there is no conversion from adsorbed oxygen to lattice oxygen. In addition, taking into considering that many literatures about oxidation reaction of NO [4], CO [32,56,57] and benzene [58] on metal-doped graphene classified oxygen atoms as adsorbed oxygen atoms, it should be reasonable for us to ignore the paths in Mars–van Krevelen mechanism. 3.3 Reaction path analysis 3.3.1 E–R reaction mechanism There are four different reaction paths in E–R mechanism taking into account of distinct modes of NO molecules attacking activated oxygen atom. Due to the substance is relative large and therefore we just remained the center part of catalyst when we pictured figures on reaction configurations. In Fig. 3 , the first reaction path has been plotted clearly, and detailed energy barriers (Ea) as well as reaction heat (ΔE) in catalytic reaction process were labeled. Originally, NO molecule attacked the oxygen atom bonded in cobalt atom on the surface of (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst, and then the bond length of oxygen molecule was enlarged from 1.39 Å (IS1) to 1.57 Å (TS1) and eventually increased to 2.82 Å (FS1). Lastly, final state (FS1) was obtained and newly generated NO2 was attached to cobalt atom directly with a large distance of 2.70 Å between nitrogen atom and cobalt atom. In this path, the energy barrier was just 0.17 eV, and huge reaction heat of 2.40 eV would be released to promote NO2 desorption afterwards. The second reaction path in E–R mechanism has been pictured in Fig. 4 and key parameters such as bond lengths, energy barriers and reaction heat were also labeled in corresponding plots. At the beginning, the NO molecule attacked the same oxygen atom as path1 through a distinct approach, and then it formed an intermediate (IM1) with a slight energy barrier of 0.19 eV. In the meanwhile, the bond length of oxygen molecule was stretched obviously from 1.37 Å (IS2) to 1.60 Å (TS2) and eventually improved to 2.72 Å (IM1). Afterwards, desorption structure (FS1) of NO2 molecule from catalyst surface was obtained with a pretty low energy barrier of 0.09 eV, and it is obvious that path2 shared the same desorption structure with path1. Both reaction steps of IS2 to IM1 as well as IM1 to FS1 are exothermic reaction, and their reaction heat are -2.05 eV and -0.17 eV, respectively. The third reaction path is that a NO molecule attacked the oxygen atom bonded on iron atom by the surface of catalyst, and the detailed reaction path diagram has been plotted in Fig. 5 . First of all, NO molecule interacted with the target oxygen atom bonded to iron atom, and then turned around to another side of OO axis to form the configuration of IM2, with a slight energy barrier of 0.16 eV. Afterwards, the bond length of N(NO)-O(O2) was becoming smaller and smaller to generate NO2 molecule (FS2). In path3, the reaction heat are -0.06 eV and -2.64 eV respectively in two reaction steps. The fourth path in E–R mechanism has been found and we can observe the whole process in Fig. 6 . Firstly, the NO molecule was coming closely to the oxygen atom connected to iron atom, and in this process of attacking oxygen, the bond length of N(NO)-O(O2) was shortened from 2.08 Å (IS4) to 2.01 Å (TS6) and then decreased to 1.86 Å (IM3), getting over a low energy barrier of 0.21 eV. After going through a transition state (TS7) and corresponding energy barrier of 0.37 eV, the IM3 was converted to NO2, with a huge heat release of 2.47 eV. Moreover, it was easily obtained that path4 shared the same desorption configuration with path3, and the reaction heat are -0.05 eV and -2.47 eV respectively in path4 (Fig. 7 ). 3.3.2 L–H reaction mechanism Taking into the most stable co-adsorption configuration of NO and O2 shown in Fig. 2, the initial state (IS5) of reaction path in L–H mechanism was determined in this research. At the beginning, the oxygen was activated, as manifested by the bond length of OO was increased from 1.39 Å (IS5) to 2.63 Å (IM4). Then, the NO molecule would draw near the oxygen atom bonded on iron atom to form another intermediate state (IM5). Afterwards, the activated oxygen molecule reversed and an oxygen atom would be attached to NO molecule to produce NO2 molecule (IM6). Finally, the desorption structure (FS5) was acquired via a transition state (TS11). In reaction path in L–H mechanism, the energy barrier could reach 0.91 eV, which is larger than that in E–R mechanism obviously. 3.3.3 Reaction mechanism of NO oxidation by residual oxygen atom Through calculations above, five paths in two mechanisms of NO oxidation on (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst have been revealed. However, there is still one oxygen atom connected on catalyst surface as shown in Fig. 2(a). In order to complete the cycle of catalytic oxidation reaction and ensure the integrity of our work, the catalytic oxidation path of NO by residual oxygen atom was explored, which has been shown in Fig. 8 . In this path, the residual oxygen atom was removed by NO molecule going through two transition states, and the energy barrier was less than 0.13 eV. 3.3.4 Energy profiles analysis 3.3.4.1 Energy profiles of NO oxidation In order to describe energy variation under distinct paths conveniently, the energy profiles were plotted into pictures, as shown in Fig. 9 . Herein, the total energy of reactants was defined as zero point energy, and the reaction process could be divided into two steps, as present in equations below:(* represents adsorbed state of gases) N O + O 2 * → N O 2 + O * N O + O * → N O 2 The first stage pictures the oxidation of first NO, by attacking the first oxygen atom of adsorbed oxygen molecule. For four paths in E–R mechanism, the energy barriers of NO oxidation (IS→FS) are very low, with values under 0.17 eV, 0.19 eV, 0.35 eV and 0.37 eV respectively, and therefore it should be very easy for oxidation of first NO on (Fe,Co)-N/GN catalyst, even at low temperature. For the path in L-H mechanism, the energy barrier of first NO oxidation is about 0.91 eV, and though the value is obviously larger than that in E–R mechanism, it is still slight enough to guarantee the oxidation of NO at room temperature. In addition, the second equation represents the oxidation reaction of second NO on the surface of catalyst, and it is obviously that the energy barrier in the process of NO oxidation is about 0.14 eV, indicating this reaction is also very easy to take place using (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst. Based on analysis above, we can conclude that (Fe,Co)/N-GN is a compelling catalyst for NO oxidation. In order to guarantee the next cycle of catalytic reaction on catalyst surface, after NO is oxidized to NO2, generated NO2 must desorb from catalyst surface (FS→P). Thus, the desorption analysis was carried out to further understand the catalytic oxidation of NO on the surface of (Fe,Co)-N/GN catalyst. From Fig. 9, we can clearly find that NO2 desorption energy barriers are much larger than that of NO oxidation, with the values of 2.26 eV (path1/path2), 2.48 eV (path3/path4), 1.52 eV (path5), and 2.85 eV (path6) respectively, but it is obvious that the desorption barrier of FS3 to P1 is just 1.52 eV (path5), which is low enough to free the NO2 molecule considering the extremely high temperature of boiler gas. Therefore, not only the oxidation reaction of first NO can easily occur, but also the generated NO2 can desorb from catalyst surface via L-H mechanism with a small energy barrier of 1.52 eV, suggesting the oxidation reaction of first NO tend to take place in L-H mechanism in most cases. The desorption of NO2 from second stage of NO oxidation was considered, and compared to its small oxidation energy barrier of 0.14 eV, the desorption energy barrier was up to 2.85 eV, suggesting it was relative hard for NO2 to desorb from catalyst surface. Yang et al [4] carried out a similar investigation of NO catalytic oxidation on the surface of single atom iron catalyst based on graphene (Fe/GN), and they also observed large desorption energy barrier of NO2 (2.07 eV) like this work. Even though the energy barrier value was not small, they thought the reaction can take place due to the extremely high temperature of flue gas, and according to previous study of zhang et al [59], the flue gas with high temperature of coal-fired power plants can make reaction with 4.5 eV energy barrier take place, therefore it should be not a big problem of NO2 desorption for NO oxidation. 3.3.4.2 The effect of CO on removal of residual oxygen atom Furthermore, in flue gas, NO and CO molecules can exist at the same time, and therefore it is natural for us to consider the effect of CO on NO oxidation using (Fe,Co)-N/GN catalyst. Large amount of literatures proved that the catalytic oxidation of CO molecule did not suffer from the issue of CO2 desorption [60,61], because there was not unpaired electron in CO2 electronic configuration, making CO2 inactive and desorption more easily happen than NO2. Besides, according to our previous investigations [3,4], CO can interact with residual oxygen atom on carbonaceous materials easily, including activated carbon [3] and single metal atom catalyst based on graphene [4]. Hence, it is very likely that CO molecule attack the residual oxygen atom on catalyst surface to finish the cycle of catalytic oxidation, replacing the second NO oxidation reaction with high desorption barrier. In order to verify this argument, we further calculated the CO oxidation reaction by reacting with residual oxygen atom, and got the detailed reaction path, as shown in Fig. 10 . It is observed that the energy barrier of CO oxidation on the surface of (Fe,Co)-N/GN catalyst is 0.58 eV, and the desorption energy barrier of CO2 on (Fe,Co)-N/GN is just -0.08 eV by our theoretical calculation. Moreover, the most stable adsorption configuration of CO2 on the surface of catalyst was given in Fig.S1 to describe its largest desorption energy barrier of all possible reaction paths. As a result, the biggest desorption energy of CO2 was just -0.30 eV, and therefore CO catalytic oxidation should be more likely to take place in the second step of catalytic oxidation reaction. In addition, the co-adsorption of CO and O2 on the surface of (Fe,Co)-N/GN is just -0.50 eV by calculation (see Fig.S1), and this value is far less than that of NO and O2 co-adsorption, indicating NO catalytic oxidation still plays the main role in the first step. Hence oxidation reaction should be divided into two stages: NO*+O2*→NO2+O* (energy barrier: 1.50 eV) CO + O*→CO2 (energy barrier: 0.58 eV) Obviously, the effect of NO catalytic oxidation mainly attributed to the first oxidation step via the path of L-H mechanism, and therefore we would focus our attention on the first oxidation stage in this investigation to explore the catalytic oxidation of NO molecule (Fig. 11 ). 3.4 Thermodynamic analysis From reaction path analysis above, we have obtained the detailed reaction process, and then well understood the energy profiles of NO oxidation in different mechanisms. In addition, the reaction energy (ΔG) as well as corresponding equilibrium constant (K) should be further investigated in order to get the thermodynamic characteristic of NO catalytic oxidation at different temperatures. The reaction energy and the logarithm of corresponding reaction equilibrium constant at distinct temperature were given in Fig.12 , respectively. From Fig.12(a), the reaction energies of NO oxidation through all paths are below zero, demonstrating those NO oxidation reactions can take place spontaneously among the range of research temperature. From Fig.12(b), the equilibrium constants are always decreasing with the improvement of reaction temperature, indicating high reaction temperature can make the chemical equilibrium of NO catalytic oxidation go to the reverse reaction direction. Obviously, the equilibrium constants of all paths (path1 to path5) are larger than 105 from 298.15 K to 1000 K, demonstrating the first NO catalytic oxidation reaction can happen completely and irreversibly using (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst. For the second NO catalytic oxidation reaction (path6), it may well not be carried out completely and irreversibly when flue gas temperature is higher than 500 K. However, considering the promoting role of CO played in removing the residual O atom, it can hardly become a huge obstacle for next cycle of catalytic oxidation reaction, because CO oxidation reaction may replace NO oxidation reaction at this stage. Therefore, the catalytic oxidation of NO on the surface of (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst is favorable in thermodynamics. 3.5 Kinetic analysis The speed of catalytic oxidation reaction is also important to further understand the effect of (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst. Herein, kinetics analysis was carried out to obtain kinetic properties of different reaction paths, and it can further lay a foundation for micro-kinetics calculation. According to previous analysis, the energy barrier of NO oxidation is extremely slight, but the desorption of generated NO2 is relatively hard. Therefore, we selected the desorption process of each path (path1 to path5) as the rate-determining step, and according to conventional transition state theory, the reaction rate constant can be acquired easily, as shown in Fig.13 . From Fig.13, it is clear that the reaction rate constants are always increasing with the improvement of temperatures, which suggests that high temperature can accelerate the catalytic oxidation of NO obviously. Particularly, the reaction rate constant of the path5 in L-H mechanism at high temperature are fast enough to ensure the normal occurrence of catalytic reaction. Furthermore, Arrhenius equation of each rate determining step for distinct reaction paths was obtained from linear fitting of the reaction rate constants above, and the parameters including pre-exponential factor (A) as well as activation energy (Ea) was tabulated in Table 3 . Given the temperature level of flue gas in coal-fired boilers, all five reaction paths should be relatively easy to happen, and among all paths involved in this work, the activation energy of NO oxidation reaction in path5 is obvious slight, indicating that the oxidation reaction of NO in L-H mechanism can easily take place with relative high reaction speed. 3.6 The effect of H2O and SO2 on catalytic reaction H2O and SO2 molecules have been seen as negative gases for catalytic reaction in flue gas, because they tend to compete for active sites with reactants at the beginning of reactions [62]. According to analysis above, adsorption of O2 and co-adsorption of NO as well as O2 are the first stage of NO catalytic oxidation in E–R mechanism and L-H mechanism respectively. Therefore it is necessary to investigate the adsorption order to further understand the effect of SO2 and H2O on reaction. (Adsorption configurations were given in Fig.S2.) In Fig.14 , we can clearly observed that adsorption energy of H2O molecule on (Fe,Co)/N-GN was the lowest among all gases, and the weak interaction between H2O and catalyst indicated H2O can hardly occupy active sites on catalyst surface, demonstrating H2O molecule has little effect on NO oxidation. As for SO2 molecule, it seemed that SO2 would inhibit NO oxidation in E–R mechanism because its adsorption energy was larger than that of O2. However, according to analysis above, L-H mechanism is the main reaction path, and the co-adsorption energy of NO and O2 is obviously larger than that of SO2 when the temperature is lower than 800 K. Therefore SO2 could not suppress NO oxidation in L-H mechanism under 800 K, demonstrating (Fe,Co)/N-GN owing outstanding anti-poisoning capacity for H2O and SO2. Compared to works of literature [16], the lowest oxidation energy barrier of NO molecule oxidation via O2 on the surface of single atom silicon catalyst doped on boron-nitride nanotubes is just 0.01 eV, which is far lower than our calculated energy barrier, indicating the catalytic oxidation of NO on the single atom silicon catalyst is better than that on (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst. However, the desorption energy barrier of generated NO2 from catalyst surface was not considered in that research, leading to great puzzle to its correctness. Moreover, each path of the catalytic oxidation of NO on the surface of single atom silicon catalyst was not favorable in thermodynamics, and according to above calculations, the first stage of NO oxidation on the surface of (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst can take place spontaneously and irreversibly. Therefore, (Fe,Co)/N-GN should be a great catalyst for NO oxidation based on thermodynamic analysis and kinetic analysis. 4 Conclusions Adsorption property and related reaction mechanism of NO and O2 using (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst were studied through DFT calculation systematically. The corresponding reaction paths by E–R and L–H mechanism were involved and thermodynamic and kinetic analysis were also carried out to further understand the effect of temperature on equilibrium constant and reaction rate. According to calculations above, we concluded that: 1 The oxidation reaction can be divided into two stages: NO*+O2*→NO2+O*、CO + O*→CO2, and the NO oxidation mainly attributed to the first oxidation stage. 2 For oxidation of NO, it can take place easily with small energy barriers of 0.17 eV, 0.19 eV, 0.35 eV, 0.37 eV and 0.91 eV, however, the corresponding desorption of generated NO2 is relative tough, among which the energy barrier of path5 in L-H mechanism is low enough with a value of 1.5 eV, and therefore the NO oxidation should take place in L-H mechanism in most cases. 3 Thermodynamic analysis evidenced these reactions can take place completely and irreversibly because the logarithm of equilibrium constant is more than 105 at high temperature. 4 Kinetic analysis further indicated the reaction rates of rate-determining steps are fast enough to ensure the normal processing of corresponding reactions in boilers. Therefore, (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst can be an ideal candidate for NO oxidation in coal-fired power plants. 5 H2O has little effect on NO oxidation, and SO2 can hardly inhibit NO oxidation under 800 K. coredata.dc:description: Nitric oxide (NO) releasing from power plants has caused global concerns. Converting NO to NO2 by catalytic oxidation technology is a promising method for NO elimination. Adsorption characteristics of corresponding gases and mechanism of NO oxidation on the surface of (Fe,Co)/N-GN catalyst were systematically investigated via density functional theory calculation. The detailed reaction paths in mechanism of Eley-Rideal and Langmuir-Hinshelwood were studied respectively and the thermodynamic and kinetic analysis of each path were performed to further understand the impact of temperature on the chemical equilibrium constant and reaction rate constant. It was observed that NO can be easily oxidized to NO2 on the surface of (Fe,Co)/N-GN with the smallest energy barriers about 0.17 eV in E–R mechanism, but the oxidation of NO in boiler is more likely to take place in L-H mechanism due to lower desorption barrier of generated NO2. Besides, we found CO played a promoting role in removal of residual oxygen atom, and H2O and SO2 had little impact on reaction under 800 K. We hope this work can not only lay a foundation for theoretical study of NO oxidation, but also provide a guideline for NO elimination in the coal-fired power plants.
coredata.dc:title: Bimetallic sites supported on N-doped graphene ((Fe,Co)/N-GN) as a new catalyst for NO oxidation: A theoretical investigation
